description.narrative: Community Development and Knowledge Management for the Satoyama Initiative (COMDEKS) - Phase 3

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).

description.narrative: To develop sound biodiversity management and sustainable livelihood activities with local communities to maintain, rebuild, and revitalize socio-ecological production landscapes and seascapes (SEPLS), through the following sub-objectives: (i). Local organizations and institutions have the understanding, strategies, tools, skills and technical capacities required to implement socio-ecological production landscape initiatives in COMDEKS participating countries. (ii). Practitioners at the global, national, and local levels and local stakeholders’ access and exchange knowledge, experience, best practices and lessons from socio-ecological production landscapes, to incorporate lessons learned into planning tools and enable replication and upscaling of best practices around the world.

comment.narrative: The Community Development and Knowledge Management for the Satoyama Initiative (COMDEKS) Programme is a unique global programme implemented by the UNDP as a flagship program of the International Partnership for the Satoyama Initiative, a global initiative to promote sustainable use and management of natural resources in socio-ecological production landscapes and seascapes (SEPLS) with the aim of maintaining, rebuilding and revitalizing them. COMDEKS was established with the CBD Secretariat, founded through the Japan Biodiversity Fund, and designed as a five-year programme implemented by UNDP, in partnership with the Ministry of the Environment of Japan (MOEJ), the Secretariat of the Convention on Biological Diversity (SCBD), the United Nations University (UNU). The Programme collects and distributes knowledge and experiences from successful on-the-ground actions for replication, policy dialogue and up-scaling in other parts of the world.

Promoting sustainability and upscaling of SEPL conservation approach, including efforts to – encourage sustainable use of biodiversity and its integration into the management of land, forest, and water resources (COP decision XII/18); provide further guidance on the concept of sustainability in food and agriculture with particular focus on biodiversity; to promote and strengthen support for relevant information-sharing and technology transfer among Parties (COP decision XIII/3); and Institutionalize these SEPLs as other effective area-based conservation measures, wherever relevant (COP decision XIV/8)

COMDEKS was found relevant to the objectives of various organizations like Satoyama Initiative, Aichi Biodiversity Targets, GEF, UNDP, SGP, countries and landscape stakeholders. It completed the planned activities and successfully achieved the agreed indicators and targets, and many of them exceeded the agreed targets in significant proportions. It has also operated above the historical average level of SGP projects’ efficiency. It has achieved diverse impacts at the landscape level. These impacts from the projects have multiplied and far exceeded the initial investment and scope of their activities. In this sense, COMDEKS has worked as a real incubator of initiatives that have scaled up and prospered beyond COMDEKS support.

Promoting sustainability and upscaling of SEPL conservation approach, including efforts to – encourage sustainable use of biodiversity and its integration into the management of land, forest, and water resources (COP decision XII/18); provide further guidance on the concept of sustainability in food and agriculture with particular focus on biodiversity; to promote and strengthen support for relevant information-sharing and technology transfer among Parties (COP decision XIII/3); and Institutionalize these SEPLs as other effective area-based conservation measures, wherever relevant (COP decision XIV/8)

The landscape approach adopted by COMDEKS allows for community level bottom-up processes towards sustainability. This has been highlighted by the impacts that have been achieved during a relatively short timeframe as well as their permanence beyond COMDEKS funding at country level (at least 18-24 months). In addition, COMDEKS also has validated the importance of having a participatory baseline assessment of the landscape which has to fulfills several goals, such as connecting different stakeholders in the landscape and facilitating their interaction; developing a common view of the landscape and its desired future; jointly identifying intervention priorities for the landscape; and, as a logical consequence, establishing or strengthening the basis for local networking, knowledge management, and effective local governance. The landscape approach in SGP Upgraded Country Programmes (UCP) has a significant outcome in terms of replication. Using GEF co-financing, 15 GEF SGP UCPs in Bolivia, Brazil, Costa Rica, Ecuador, India, Kenya, Mexico, Pakistan, Philippines, Egypt, Indonesia, Kazakhstan, Peru, Sri Lanka, and Thailand are replicating the landscape approach during GEF OP6, using tools and instruments developed with COMDEKS support, and building on the programme’s lessons and best practices.

Promoting sustainability and upscaling of SEPL conservation approach, including efforts to – encourage sustainable use of biodiversity and its integration into the management of land, forest, and water resources (COP decision XII/18); provide further guidance on the concept of sustainability in food and agriculture with particular focus on biodiversity; to promote and strengthen support for relevant information-sharing and technology transfer among Parties (COP decision XIII/3); and Institutionalize these SEPLs as other effective area-based conservation measures, wherever relevant (COP decision XIV/8)

The majority of COMDEKS Phase 1 and Phase 2 countries have completed the ex-post baseline assessments in order to evaluate achievements, produce videos and case studies with stories from the target landscapes, and develop recommendations for the future. COMDEKS was active in a number of global and regional forums and events and has continued to place a large emphasis on knowledge management activities. COMDEKS lessons and models have also provided valuable inputs to the development of the landscape and seascape approaches now being adopted by the SGP Country Programmes for GEF-6 as well as critical inputs for the development of the GEF-7 SGP strategy and approach.
